Reviewer_1;Author;1;1;0;The abstract is very confusingly written and needs a lot of editing. This is the place where the story must be told as simply and clearly as possible
column2: and I think a lot of the abstract is confusing and hard to interpret.

column1: Reviewer_1;Author;1;2;0;I have some theoretical questions about the applicability of these approaches outside of Korea. For technical reasons (most smart cities have less capability and are less developed than Korean ones)
column2: but especially for legal and normative reasons (concerns about surveillance
column5: etc.) I think many cities and countries will not be comfortable with this approach. I think this needs some exploration.

column1: Reviewer_1;Author;1;3;0;I'd argue that one of the areas in which Smart City applications (in particular) and urban automation (in general) have been most important during the COVID pandemic - the monitoring of sewage and wastewater for population level assessment of infection - isn't even mentioned. I think that is both a big oversight
column2: and an opportunity for critics. I think that piece needs to be included and worked into any assessment of smart cities and pandemics. Additionally
column3: I've included a few other pieces on COVID and smart cities.

Reviewer_2;Author;1;11;0;"The contribution is a proposition of services such as screening people with thermal cameras and
tracking infected people through CCTV. However
column2: it misses a critical point of COVID. Infected

column1: people are in the public space without knowing that they have COVID
column2: since contagion happens

column1: before symptoms appears. Once infected people have been identified
column2: they are supposedly in

column1: quarantine. Do the authors propose to track everyone and then go back to the records of infected
people to retrieve their paths and contacts? Or do the authors want to check if infected people
are outside their home instead of in quarantine? This is not clear to me. Also
column2: and more

column1: importantly
column2: the integration and flexibility aspects are not really addressed in the end. The

column1: authors do not explain how the services they propose could be integrated with existing ones (e.g.
which standards should be used) and how the services can be added or removed. This part is only
represented as clouds in the proposed structure model but not discussed further. Therefore
column2: it

column1: seems that the contribution breaks down to proposing strict tracking services which feasibility
and acceptance by the population is not assessed."
